title: Visualizing Plasmon Mediated Metal Deposition and Gold Nanorod Reshaping with Liquid Phase Transmission Electron Microscopy
content: Plasmonic nanoparticles convert incident light to highly excited charge carriers (“hot” electrons and holes) that can drive redox reactions at the particle surface [1,2]. Plasmonic hot electrons may reduce metal ions to deposit secondary, catalytically active metals onto colloidal plasmonic noble metal nanoparticles, generating highly efficient photocatalysts [2]. In conjunction with simulation methods [3], high resolution in situ experimental measurements can contribute to developing comprehensive understanding of hot carrier dynamics. Liquid phase transmission electron microscopy (LP-TEM) can uniquely visualize nanometer-scale phenomena in liquid in real time, including secondary metal deposition on seed nanoparticles [4-7]. The TEM electron beam acts an evanescent broadband light source that generates surface plasmons in metallic nanostructures [6]. Prior work by Sun et al. showed the electron beam during LP-TEM imaging of colloidal silver (Ag) nanoparticles induced shape transformations [6]. However, both LSPR mediated chemistry and radiolysis can drive aqueous phase redox chemistry during LP-TEM, obscuring the precise reaction mechanism. Radiation chemistry often dominates reaction pathways due to production of strongly oxidizing and reducing radicals such as hydroxyl radicals (OH•), solvated electrons (es), and hydrogen radicals (H•) by electron beam water radiolysis [8]. For instance, Chen et al. found Ag deposition on plasmonic gold nanorods (AuNRs) in water during LP-TEM was consistent with ligand-mediated chemical reduction by radicals, as opposed to LSPR hot electron driven reactions [7]. Application of LP-TEM to probe plasmon-mediated redox processes requires establishing strategies to minimize solvent radiolysis and accumulation of redox-active radicals.
